title-group.article-title: In vivo evaluation of the interaction between titanium dioxide nanoparticle and rat liver DNA

article-meta.aff: 1Institute of Biophysics, Second Military Medical University, Shanghai, People’s Republic of China
2Shanghai Synchrotron Radiation Facility, Shanghai, People’s Republic of China

author-notes.corresp: Y Ji Yang, Institute of Biophysics, Second Military Medical University, Shanghai 200433, People’s Republic of China. Email: yjyang@smmu.edu.cn

abstract.p: Titanium dioxide nanoparticles (TiO2 NPs) are massively produced and widely used in daily life, which may pose potential risk to human health via uncharacterized interaction between DNAs. This research aims to examine the interaction between DNA and three types of TiO2 NPs of different sizes and crystallines. The interaction between TiO2 NPs and liver DNA molecules obtained from Sprague-Dawley rats was systematically evaluated in vivo using atomic force microscopy, transmission electron microscopy, various spectroscopic techniques and gel electrophoresis. We found that TiO2 NPs (diameter <25 nm and <100 nm) in anatase crystalline can covalently interact with liver DNA by either inserting itself in between DNA base pairs or binding to DNA nucleotide via P–O–Ti–O bond. Such interaction may not be NP size-dependent but may be crystalline phase-dependent, because such interaction did not occur in rutile crystal phase, in which the DNA damage was potentially caused by reactive oxygen species.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: With the advance of nanotechnology, nanoparticles (NPs), with a scale of 1–100 nm, are widely used in electronics, optical devices, medical imaging, drug delivery as well as consumer products such as sunscreens, textiles, cosmetics, and so on (Han et al., 2009; Lee et al., 2008). While the high surface area to volume ratio of NPs offers venues toward exciting novel applications, the unique physiochemical properties of NPs may also impose serious hazard to human health and environment, for example, the large surface area of NPs creates enhanced reactivity with other molecules and their small size allows greater penetration and mobility through the human body. A number of studies have suggested that the nanoscale particles are more toxic than the particles of larger size (Donaldson et al., 2001, 2004; Dreher, 2004; Nel et al., 2006; Xia et al., 2006), and as the use of NPs is becoming more prevalent, their safety concerns and health-related effects need to be addressed (Chhabra et al., 2009; Funk et al., 2007; Karlsson et al., 2009; Oberdorster et al., 2005).

Titanium dioxide (TiO2) is a metal oxide NP commonly used in paints, plastics, inks, paper, creams and cosmetics. TiO2 has different crystal forms, including rutile, anatase and amorphous (Wiesenthal et al., 2011). Recent studies showed that exposure to high concentrations of TiO2 NPs can induce lung inflammatory responses and tumors in rodents (Bermudez et al., 2004; Sun et al., 2009; Wang et al., 2009). TiO2 NPs can also elicit various degrees of cytotoxicity in renal and neural cells (L'Azou et al., 2008; Lai et al., 2008). One of the characteristics of the NPs-induced toxicity is the production of reactive oxygen species (ROS), which leads to oxidative stress (OS) and ultimately cell death (Wiesenthal et al., 2011). Several in vitro studies have reported that TiO2 NPs caused OS-mediated cytotoxicity in cells from liver, skin, endothelia, epithelia, Salmonella bacteria and alveolar macrophages. Interestingly, it has been suggested that TiO2 NPs toxicity depends on crystalline phase rather than particle size (Jin et al., 2010; Sayes et al., 2006; Warheit et al., 2007). The photocatalytic activity of the anatase form of TiO2 NPs is higher than rutile form and anatase form can induce higher cytotoxicity than rutile form (Gurr et al., 2005; Xia et al., 2006). In addition, pure anatase TiO2 NPs could induce necrosis and membrane leakage independent of ROS generation, whereas rutile TiO2 NP-initiated apoptosis is via the formation of ROS (Braydich-Stolle et al., 2009). Nevertheless, the detailed mechanisms of the TiO2 NP-induced toxicity are currently unknown.

Nucleic acids are one of the primary targets of ROS. Previously, it was reported that carbon and zinc oxide NPs can directly interact with DNA (An et al., 2010; Nel et al., 2006; Taratula et al., 2009; Zhang et al., 2010). Recently, Li et al. (2010), showed that anatase-TiO2 NPs can insert itself into DNA double strands and alter their secondary structure. However, the details of such interaction between TiO2 NPs and DNA were not fully characterized, and we still lack the information whether various forms of TiO2 NPs may contribute to its interaction with DNA differently. In this study, we characterized the in vivo interaction between DNA and TiO2 NPs of different sizes and crystalline phases in rats. Our results revealed a dramatic difference in the DNA interaction between different forms of TiO2 NPs and provide a potential explanation to the divergent cellular responses induced by different TiO2 NPs.

sec.title: TiO2 particle
sec.p: Nano-anatase TiO2 particles (d < 25 nm), micro-rutile TiO2 particles (d < 5 μm) and a mixture of 5–10% rutile and 90–95% anatase TiO2 NPs (Jin et al., 2010) (d < 100 nm) without any coating were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich (St Louis, Missouri, USA). TiO2 particle size in pure anatase was measured by wide angle x-ray diffractometry; particle size in pure rutile and in a mixture of anatase and rutile was measured by Brunauer–Emmett–Teller method.

The initial TiO2 NPs in dried powder form without any further treatment were suspended in ultrapure distilled water and the dispersion was ultrasonicated for 30 min at 25°C. The dispersion was then dripped onto 300-mesh copper grids. The dispersion of TiO2 particles was examined using a Hitachi H-7650 transmission electron microscope (Tokyo, Japan) with an attached Gatan digital camera (Gatan, Pleasanton, USA).

sec.title: Animal handling
sec.p: Sprague-Dawley rats (5 weeks old, 120–150 g) were purchased from the Animal House Center at the Chinese Academy of Science (Shanghai, China). The animals were housed in plastic microisolator cages under controlled environmental conditions (relative humidity of 60 ± 10%, at a room temperature of 20.0 ± 2.0°C and 12 h light: dark cycle). Distilled water and sterilized food were provided ad libitum. All procedures used in animal experiments were approved by Animal Ethics Committee of Second Military Medical University. Rats were randomly divided into control group and three treatment groups with pure anatase, pure rutile and mixture of anatase and rutile, respectively. TiO2 particle dispersion was administrated intranasally (300 μg per rat) every day for 45 days. Control group animals were treated with sterile water. During the course of the experiment, no abnormal daily activity was observed in all rats.

sec.title: Rat liver DNA isolation
sec.p: Upon the completion of the treatment, rat livers from control and treatment groups were excised and washed with saline. DNA was isolated using Animal Cells/Tissue Genomic DNA Extraction Kit according to the manufacturer’s protocol (Beijing Solarbio Science and Technology Co., Ltd., Tongzhou, Beijing, China). DNA concentration and absorbance at OD260/OD280 were determined using ultraviolet–visible (UV-VIS) absorption spectroscopy, and DNA integrity was examined using agarose gel electrophoresis.

sec.title: μ-SRXRF spectrum
sec.p: DNA isolated from rat livers was subject to agarose gel electrophoresis, and the DNA bands were excised and analyzed using the micro-synchrotron radiation x-ray fluorescence (μ-SRXRF) at BL-15U beamline in Shanghai Synchrotron Radiation Facility (Shanghai, China). The electron energy and ring current of the synchrotron light source were 3.5 GeV and 160~210 mA, respectively. Kirkpatric-Baez optics was used to focus the monochromatic x-ray beam to square spots size to 5 × 5 μm2. The 7-elements Si(Li) detector with the energy resolution of 140 eV at 5.9 keV was used to collect data. The one-dimensional step-by-step scanning model was used to investigate the distribution of titanium (Ti) element in the DNA samples embedded in the agarose gel.

sec.title: Atomic force microscopy
sec.p: Atomic force microscopic (AFM) images were acquired using a nanoscope three-dimensional multimode scanning probe microscopy (Veeco Instruments Inc., Santa Barbara, California, USA) operated in tapping mode with RTESP probes (40 N m− 1, 300 kHz, Veeco Probes, Camarillo, California, USA) in air at ambient conditions (25°C). The instrument was mounted on a vibration isolation table to reduce environmental noise. Before imaging, sample loading surface was pretreated with 10 mM nickel nitrate. Nickel nitrate solution of 20 μL was pipetted onto a parafilm membrane and covered using newly cleaved mica (An et al., 2005). After 3 min, the mica was repeatedly washed with distilled water and blown dry using liquid nitrogen. Rat liver DNA solutions of 10 μL from control and treatment groups were deposited onto pretreated mica surface. After 3 min, the samples were blown dry using liquid nitrogen and were visualized by atomic force microscopy. Images were collected with a scan range of 80 × 80 × 5 μm3 in x-80um, y-80um and z-5um axes, respectively.

sec.title: Transmission electron microscopy
sec.p: Liver DNA solutions were deposited on a thin carbon film covering 200-mesh copper grids, air dried and then stained with uranyl acetate and lead nitrate for 12 min. Samples were examined using a Hitachi H-7650 transmission electron microscope (Tokyo, Japan) with an attached Gatan digital camera.

sec.title: Characterization of TiO2 particles dispersion in water
sec.p: Nano-anatase TiO2 particles (d < 25 nm) have a surface area of 200 m2 g−1; micro-rutile TiO2 particles (d < 5 μm) have a surface area of 2.5 m2 g−1 and the mixture of rutile and anatase TiO2 NPs (d < 100 nm) have a surface area of 15 m2 g−1. TiO2 particles of different sizes were dispersed in ultrapure water. As shown in transmission electron microscopic (TEM) images in Figure 1, particles of all sizes were well dispersed in water. In addition, consistent with our previous x-ray absorption fine structure results (Jin et al., 2010), the majority of the particles present in the mixture (d < 100 nm) were in the anatase form.

caption.p: Transmission electron microscopic images of titanium dioxide nanoparticles dispersed in Milli-Q water: ((a) d < 25 nm; (b) d < 100 nm; (c) d < 5 μm).

sec.title: UV-VIS absorption spectra of liver DNA from control and TiO2 NP-treated rats
sec.p: The absorption spectra of rat liver DNA from control and three different types of TiO2 particle treatment groups are shown in Figure 2. The results showed that there was a decrease in 260 nm absorbance in groups treated with nano-anatase TiO2 and the mixture of anatase and rutile TiO2 NPs compared with control group. However, no decrease in 260 nm absorbance was observed in the group treated with micro-rutile TiO2 particles. Baseline correction was made for all measurements to rule out potential systematic errors. It was previously reported that the decrease in absorbance at 260 nm was due to the interaction between TiO2 and DNA (Li et al., 2010). Our results suggested that nano-anatase TiO2 particles, but not micro-rutile TiO2 particles, can interact with genomic DNA in water. In addition, TiO2 NPs in the anatase form might bind to the surface of DNA and form a complex as suggested by apparent blue shifts and significant hypochromicities observed at 210 nm.

caption.p: Ultraviolet absorption spectra of DNA from liver of rats treated with three different types TiO2 NPs and control vehicle. (a) DNA from control group; (b) DNA from nano-anatase TiO2 particle-treated group (d < 25 nm); (c) DNA from the mixture of rutile and anatase TiO2 NP-treated group (d < 100 nm); (d) DNA from micro-rutile TiO2 particle-treated group (d < 5μm). TiO2: titanium dioxide; NPs: nanoparticles.

sec.title: Agarose gel electrophoresis of DNA from control group and groups treated with different TiO2 particles
sec.p: Agarose gel eletrophoresis was performed to evaluate potential DNA cleavage resulted from TiO2 particles treatment. As shown in Figure 3, DNA from control and all three treatment groups contained much DNA fragments.

caption.p: DNA agarose gel eletrophoresis of DNA from control and treatment groups. (a) DNA ladder; (b) DNA from control group; (c) DNA from nano-anatase TiO2 particle-treated group (d < 25 nm); (d) DNA from mixture of rutile and anatase TiO2 NP-treated group (d < 100 nm); (e) DNA from micro-rutile TiO2 particle-treated group (d < 5μm). TiO2: titanium dioxide; NPs: nanoparticles.

sec.title: The distribution of Ti element in the agarose gel during electrophoresis
sec.p: The microdistribution of Ti element in agarose gel during electrophoresis was quantitatively measured using microbeam scanning technique of SRXRF. As the scanning size of x-ray beam was 5 × 5 μm2, the absolute detection limit of SRXRF was 10−12 to 10−15 g. In the control group, the concentration of Ti element in DNA was below the detection limit of SRXRF and the spectrum was therefore not available. In the group treated with nano-anatase TiO2 particles, Ti element was rich in the position about 38 mm to the comb well of the agarose gel, which was the highlight position in the agarose gel. It means that Ti elements only exist in DNA fragment, which suggests that TiO2 NPs might insert into the DNA fragments and co-migrate with them. In the group treated with micro-rutile TiO2 particles, Ti element was located very close to the comb well of the agarose gel and not with the DNA fragments, indicating that the TiO2 particles did not insert into the DNA. In the group treated with the mixure of anatase and rutile TiO2 NPs, Ti element was present in two locations, one within the DNA fragments and other close to the comb well, resembling the distribution of Ti element in nano-anatase and micro-rutile TiO2 particles treatment groups, respectively (Figure 4).

caption.p: Synchrotron radiation–x-ray fluorescence spectrum of titanium element distribution in the agarose gel. (a) DNA from nano-anatase TiO2 particle-treated group (d < 25 nm); (b) DNA from mixture of rutile and anatase TiO2 NP-treated group (d < 100 nm); (c) DNA from micro-rutile TiO2 particle-treated group (d < 5 μm). TiO2: titanium dioxide; NPs: nanoparticles; TiO2: titanium dioxide; NPs: nanoparticles. In the control group, the titanium concentration in DNA is below the detection limit of synchrotron radiation x-ray fluorescence and the spectrum is not available.

sec.title: The AFM images of liver DNA from control and TiO2 particle-treated groups
sec.p: AFM images showed that genomic DNA extracted from the liver of control rats appeared to be linear with an average height of 0.7 ± 0.1 nm, consistent with previous reports (Figure 5(a)). After nano-anatase TiO2 particle treatment, rat liver genomic DNA aggregated and formed intricated DNA networks with tangled DNA strands (height 50–80 nm). Interestingly, there were many bright particles that accumulated at the intersection of DNA strands, resembling a knob structure. These knob structures were 20–250 nm in diameter, much larger than a single nano-anatase TiO2 particle, and were likely to be the aggregates of TiO2 NPs (Figure 5(b)). DNA extracted from rats treated with the mixture of anatase and rutile TiO2 NPs exhibited similar phenotype; however, the DNA networks were less intricated and the big particle aggregates were fewer (Figure 5(c)). DNA from rats treated with micro-rutile TiO2 particles did not form network structure, instead they appeared as primarily short, bent and lumpy molecules with a few long smooth straight molecules or segments of molecules. Micro-rutile TiO2 particles did not form large aggregate-like nano-anatase TiO2 particles and they bound randomly to the disorganized DNA structure (Figure 5(d)). Although we cannot distinguish whether the interaction between DNA and various forms of TiO2 particles was the primary cause or the secondary effect of DNA damage, our results nevertheless indicated that TiO2 NPs of different crystalline phase interacted differently with DNA molecules and might play a different role in TiO2 NP-induced cytotoxicity.

caption.p: Atomic force microscopy images of rat liver DNA from control and treatment groups. (a) DNA from control group; (b) DNA from nano-anatase TiO2 particle-treated group (d < 25 nm); (c) DNA from mixture of rutile and anatase TiO2 NP-treated group (d < 100 nm); (d) DNA from micro-rutile TiO2 particle-treated group (d < 5 μm). TiO2: titanium dioxide; NPs: nanoparticles.

sec.title: TEM images of liver DNA from control group and groups treated with different TiO2 particles
sec.p: To confirm our results, transmission electron microscopy was used to further analyze the interaction between genomic DNA and TiO2 particles. TEM images showed that similar to what was observed in AFM images, genomic DNA from rats treated with nano-anatase TiO2 particles formed dense networks with prominent knob structures, which were 10–250 nm in size (Figure 6(a)). The diameter of individual particles inside the knob structure was about 10–30 nm, which was the size of TiO2 NPs, confirming the hypothesis that the knob structures were the aggregates of TiO2 NPs. The network phenotype was much less apparent in DNA from rats treated with the mixture of anatase and rutile TiO2 NPs; however, the accumulation of NPs along DNA strands in some areas was much more dramatic than nanoanatase TiO2 particle-treated DNA (Figure 6(b)). DNA from micro-rutile TiO2 particle-treated rats displayed a fragmented and disorganized morphology. Many small dense particles, which were much smaller than TiO2 NPs, were randomly distributed along the DNA fragments (Figure 6(c)). In support of our AFM results, TEM images confirmed that anatase and rutile TiO2 NPs behaved differently regarding their interaction with DNA.

caption.p: Transmisssion electron microscope images of DNA solution from rats treated with three different types of TiO2 NPs. (a) DNA from the rat without any treatment, (b) DNA from nano-anatase TiO2 particle-treated group (d < 25 nm); (c) DNA from mixture of rutile and anatase TiO2 NP-treated group (d < 100 nm); (d) DNA from micro-rutile TiO2 particle-treated group (d < 5μm). TiO2: titanium dioxide; NPs: nanoparticles.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: In recent years, the use of nanomaterials is increasing worldwide. Despite the growing concern of the possible risk that nanomaterials may impose, there is a lack of information on their potential toxicity and underlying mechanisms. Various NPs have shown cytotoxicity and/or genotoxicity and different mechanisms have been proposed, including ROS, lipid peroxidation as well as alteration of signal transduction, although the exact mechanism/mechanisms are yet to be found. In addition, it is not yet clear whether the toxicity observed is true for a wide range of particles with different sizes and chemical compositions. This study aims to characterize the interaction between DNA and three types of TiO2 NPs of different sizes and crystal forms and to elucidate the connection between cytotoxicity response and NP characteristics.

TiO2 NP-induced toxicity depends on several factors, such as crystal form, particle size, concentration and UV excitability. It has been under debate whether crystal form is more important than particle size in determining the toxicity response of TiO2 NPs. Studies have reported that TiO2 NPs of different crystal forms and sizes generate ROS under UV irradiation and induce cytotoxicity (Reeves et al., 2008; Uchino et al., 2002). It is known that oxygen radicals react with DNA molecules, cause oxidative damage to sugar–phosphate backbone or the bases and induce single- and double-strand breaks (Martinez et al., 2003). During OS, the production of free radicals and 8-oxo-7, 8-dihydro-2′ deoxyguanosine and 8-hydroxy-deoxy adenosine overwhelms the antioxidant defense capacity of the cell, causing adverse biological consequences (Gonzalez-Flecha, 2004; Vinzents et al., 2005). Our results confirmed that both nano-anatase and micro-rutile TiO2 particles can cause DNA damage in rat livers. Moreover, we demonstrated that nano-anatase TiO2 particles can directly bind to DNA molecules, while micro-rutile TiO2 particles can not. The direct interaction between DNA and nano-anatase TiO2 particles was strongly supported by AFM and TEM images as well as Ti element migration in the agarose gel during electrophoresis. The 260-nm absorbance decrease in UV spectrum provided another piece of evidence supporting the direct interaction as the decrease indicated a strong π-stacking interaction between Ti4+ and DNA molecule (Li et al., 2010). For micro-rutile TiO2 particles, although they seemed to be co-localized with fragmented DNA in AFM and TEM images, they did not co-migrate with 15,000 bp DNA fragments during electrophoresis or induce an absorbance decrease at 260 nm. Therefore, we do not think they directly interact with DNA molecules. Interestingly, our DNA agarose gel eletrophoresis results suggested that neither nano—anatase nor micro—rutile TiO2 particles causes DNA shearing or significant cleavage; however, in AFM and TEM images, DNA from samples treated with these two types of particles exhibited network or fragmented morphology, respectively. This is probably because the morphology observed in the images is the distorted DNA secondary structure caused by TiO2 particles. The DNA damage may be either primary as a direct effect of the NPs or a secondary effect due to generated ROS. Our results demonstrated that the DNA damage caused by micro-rutile TiO2 particles is likely to be a secondary effect due to ROS production whereas nano-anatase TiO2 particles may cause DNA damage by directly binding to the DNA and retorting its secondary structure.

It has been shown that TiO2 NPs in anatase form is biologically more active than in rutile form in inducing cytotoxicity and OS (Hirakawa et al., 2004). The differences between anatase and rutile forms of TiO2 NPs in DNA interaction and DNA secondary structure formation as we observed provide a potential explanation for this divergence and support the notion that crystal form is more important than particle size in cytotoxicity response determination.

To further elucidate the mechanism of anatase form of TiO2 NP-induced toxicity, we reviewed the biochemical and structural aspects of the interaction between DNA and anatase TiO2 NPs. The backbone of DNA consists of four sugar bases and phosphate groups that have the binding site of C–O–P and P=O. The backbone is negatively charged and will attract positively charged TiO2 NPs. The major component in TiO2 NPs is Ti–O, which will then react with P=O to form P–O–Ti–O, loosening C–O–P bond. It is recently reported (Li et al., 2010) that Ti in liver DNA is bound with three oxygen or nitrogen atoms and two phosphorous atoms with Ti–O(P) and Ti–P bond lengths of 1.87 and 2.38 Å, respectively (Li et al., 2010). Based on the available information, we propose a possible biochemical reaction between DNA molecules and TiO2 NPs (Figure 7). The interaction between anatase TiO2 NPs and DNA molecule could potentially introduce DNA damage and interfere with DNA repair and replication, altering normal biological/cellular functions and ultimately leading to cell death.

caption.p: The possible reaction formula of DNA molecule and anatase-titanium oxide nanoparticles.

sec.p: A better understanding of these chemicals as well as their interaction with human body and environment is needed to design safe and novel materials.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: In summary, this work characterized the difference between nano-anatase and micro-rutile TiO2 NPs in inducing DNA damage in rat livers. We demonstrated that nano-anatase TiO2 NPs can induce DNA damage by directly binding to the DNA molecules and distort the secondary structure, while micro-rutile TiO2 NPs induce DNA damage possibly through secondary effect of generating ROS. Our work confirms previous findings that crystal form of TiO2 NPs is important in determining cytotoxicity outcome and provides experimental and theoretical explanation for the potential underlying mechanism.

ack.title: Acknowledgments
ack.p: The authors thank Dr A. Guo Li, at the 15U station of the Shanghai Synchrotron Radiation Facility, and Dr J. Lin Sun, at Shanghai Jiao Tong University, for carrying out the AFM.
